The Buddha said:
That person says:
'The Buddha does not kill living beings, has no grudges, does not carry knives or sticks, teaches people to be good, has compassion for all, including insects and worms;
He also does not take others' possessions, but only wishes to give, thinks of giving in his mind, and has pity on those who rob and plunder others;

What is called sincerity is to enjoy truth without falsehood. People in the world all believe his words, have no different thoughts, and also do not have false thoughts.
He does not engage in gossip, pass on messages, or cause people to fight. If there are disputes, he reconciles them and makes everyone peaceful and secure.

There are non-Buddhist practitioners who, having received food offerings from the faithful, engage in empty and false practices, with their words and deeds not corresponding, displaying a bright and clear appearance, seeking material gain, always coveting the alms bowl;

When they no longer accept his words, he says, You should study and practice, but do you have any assurance?
The Buddha is free from the fruits of these animalistic actions.

The Buddha is free from these activities.

There are non-Buddhist practitioners who accept people's offerings of food, but then bathe, apply various fragrances to their bodies, adorn themselves, look in a mirror, hold a tall parasol, wear shoes, tie their hair, and wear pearl ornaments;

There are non-Buddhist practitioners who accept offerings from others and make a living by engaging in animal husbandry, distinguishing between swords, spears, and bows and arrows, distinguishing between men and women and their ages, and distinguishing between elephants, horses, cows, and sheep.

'There are non-Buddhist practitioners who, while receiving offerings of food from others, engage in animal husbandry to sustain themselves, and give people medicine to induce vomiting;

'There are non-Buddhist practitioners who, while receiving offerings of food from others, engage in animal husbandry to sustain themselves, call people to go east and west, perform spells to cause them to fight and argue, beat people, throw people to the ground, perform spells on women to cause them to miscarry, and perform spells on people's arms with reeds;
The Buddha has abandoned all such practices.

There are non-Buddhist practitioners who accept offerings from others but make a living through animal husbandry. They carry firewood to make a fire, chant spells over chestnut shells and grape seeds to make smoke, and chant spells to know when people will die.
The Buddha is completely free from these things.
There are non-Buddhist practitioners who accept offerings from others but make a living through animal husbandry. One person says it will rain a lot, another says it will rain a little.
One person says the harvest will be good, another says it will be bad.
One person says grain will be expensive, another says it will be cheap.

One person says the king will fall, another says a king will be established, one person says the earth will quake greatly, another says it won't.
One person said the moon would be eclipsed, while another said it would not be eclipsed.

The Buddha is free from all these things.

There are non-Buddhist practitioners who accept people's offerings of food and use animal husbandry to sustain themselves. One says, 'The king of this country will go and conquer that country, and the king of that country will come and conquer this country.' They interpret people's dreams, curse people to make them unable to speak, cause people's mouths to become mute, write for people and take their pay, keep people's accounts for them and take their pay, and distinguish good and bad colors and take their pay.

The Å›ramaá¹‡a takes one meal a day and does not eat in the evening. He eats at the proper time and is free from eating at improper times.
He knows moderation in his practice and is content with his robes and alms bowl. He eats only to his satisfaction.

It is just like a flying bird. Wherever it goes, its two wings follow it. A bhiká¹£u is also like this.
In terms of robes, bedding, food, and bowls, they take only what is sufficient. Wherever they go, their robes and bowls follow them. The bhiká¹£us are also like this.
They accept the admonitions of the wise and practice them. They contemplate their own bodies and do not engage in disputes. They contemplate the Way and what they do is peaceful and correct.
They see forms but do not give rise to thoughts, and they do not see each other fighting or changing.
They continue in tranquility, not confused or disturbed. All unfavorable and unwholesome dharmas cannot disturb their resolve. They all guard the eye faculty.
This is called the bhiká¹£us' acceptance of the admonitions of the wise.
The wise are like this, their faculties and sense doors are tranquil within, they do not think of disputes, and they take only what is sufficient in terms of food and drink.

They eat neither too much nor too little, just the right amount. They always eat only one meal a day, neither more nor less. They do not eat in order to build up strength, but only to keep the body from suffering and to have energy to practice concentration.

When eating, take only what is sufficient, contemplate the Way, practice the Way in the first and last watches of the night, and practice the Way with wondrous imperturbability.
During the day, whether sitting or walking, do not think of evil dharmas.
In the first watch of the night, either walk or sit.
In the middle of the night, lie down on the right side, with one foot on top of the other, and immediately think of arising and always wanting to see the light.
In the last watch of the night, sit again and contemplate the Way, whether walking or sitting, do not think of evil dharmas.

If you enter a prefecture, state, county, or city to beg for alms, get up early in the morning, put on your robe, take your alms bowl, and enter the prefecture, state, county, or city to beg for alms. Always guard the various faculties and keep the mind focused.

After finishing alms-round, he would eat his meal, wash his hands and feet, put away his bowl, and then enter into solitary sitting at night, either under a tree, in the open, in a mountain cave, or in a grass hut washed by water. He would sit upright, not looking left or right, free from worldly deluded thoughts, practicing with compassion, not giving rise to evil intentions towards any people, insects, or crawling creatures.
His mind would not think of evil, he would abandon desire, and be free from sleepiness, always thinking of quickly attaining concentration, practicing with the mind, not thinking of sleepiness.
He would be free from doubt and various thoughts, not speaking evil or giving rise to thoughts, with his inner mind in concentration, free from external doubts, and free from various thoughts.
Practicing, not practicing evil dharmas, his mind would not think of various thoughts, abandoning the five hindrances and defiled thoughts.

It is like a person who borrows money to do business, and when it succeeds, they repay the loan with interest and still have some left over. They are able to live comfortably, and they think to themselves with joy.
It is like a person who has been a slave for a long time, but then gains freedom and can come and go as they please. They think to themselves:

Thinking this, their mind is also filled with joy.

It is like a person who suffers from a serious illness for many years, but then encounters a good doctor who cures them. They regain their strength and can walk, come and go, and eat. Thinking to themselves:
In the past I was sick for many years, but now I have been cured and have the strength to eat and move about.
Thinking this, their mind is also filled with joy.
It is like a person carrying heavy wealth, passing through a dangerous path, the wealth and belongings are very secure and they reach a good path, the person thinks to themselves and is also joyful.

The bhiká¹£us are also like this, leaving behind the five hindrances, it is like having debts that are repaid and being released from confinement, being cured of a long-term illness, a slave being freed to become a commoner, and passing through a dangerous path and being released, the mind is joyful.

Those with little knowledge or who have not heard much will slander the TathÄgata.

If there are non-Buddhist practitioners who, in the past eon, see past events, and in countless ways each study those events, knowing the events therein, they are all within the eighteen views.ğŸ”½If there are non-Buddhist practitioners who, in the future eon, see future events, and study future events, in countless ways each understand those events, they are all within these forty-four views.

Those non-Buddhist practitioners who, in the past eon, see past events, and in countless ways each understand those events, are all within the eighteen views. There are non-Buddhist practitioners who practice eternalism and self-existence, and for the sake of the world they speak of permanence, and they are within these four views.
The Buddha said:
Why are those non-Buddhist practitioners within the four views?
Each sees permanence and speaks of it, and for the sake of the people of the world they speak of existence.
If there are non-Buddhist practitioners who practice meditation to end desires and attain the samÄdhi of suchness, they can recall events from twenty eons in the past.
That person says:

Why is it so?
I know the formation and destruction of eons in the past, but I do not know the formation and destruction of eons in the future.
That person then thinks:
Knowing past events, I abandon future events.
This is the first view.
Second, if there are non-Buddhist practitioners who end desires and attain the samÄdhi of suchness, they can recall events from forty eons in the future.
That person says:
I and the world are both permanent.
Why is it so?
I do not know the formation and destruction of eons in the past, but I only know the formation and destruction of eons in the future.
That person then abandons past events and does not know them, and thinks of future events. This is the second view.

Third, if a non-Buddhist practitioner, having severed desires, practices diligently and attains tranquility, then through the samÄdhi of the image-like concentration, he recollects the events of the past and future eighty eons, and that person says:
'I and the world are permanent.
Why is it so?
I know the times of the formation and destruction of past and future eons.
' That person then recollects the knowledge of the past and future, which is the third view.

Fourth, if there is a non-Buddhist practitioner who diligently practices and attains tranquility, and then through the samÄdhi of the image-like concentration, recollects the roots of tranquility and abides in deluded thoughts,
that person speaks to the world, saying:
'There is permanence.
Why is it so?

' This is the fourth view.
The so-called non-Buddhist paths that speak of eternalism and permanence, and those who expound permanence for the sake of worldly people, are all within these four views and cannot go beyond them.
The TathÄgata knows this, and he surpasses this with subtle knowledge. Therefore, he does not admonish them, and he is free from admonishment and attains non-action.
The TathÄgata knows the end of the arising of feelings, perceptions, and desires, and he sees with an unattached mind and understands well.
The Buddha said:
The Dharma I have realized is profound and illuminating. If there are wise disciples who hear it, they will praise the Buddha.
There are non-Buddhist practitioners who, in past eons, see past events and recall past events. In countless ways, they each enjoy expounding what they know to be true, all within the eighteen views.
What are those non-Buddhist paths?
It means that in past eons, they saw past events, remembered past events, and in countless ways, each enjoyed speaking about and knowing the events within them.
If there are non-Buddhist practitioners who each speak of eternalism and permanence, and each speaks of permanence for the sake of worldly people, they are all within the four views.
What are the non-Buddhist practitioners?
It means speaking of eternalism and permanence, and speaking of permanence for the sake of worldly people.

The other heavens, according to the Dharma, had meager blessings and virtue, and as their lifespans ended, they gradually descended and were born among humans. Second, if there are non-Buddhist practitioners who have a view of Brahma Heaven, they say:

The dharmas of form, feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness are permanent, unchanging, and not subject to death. The earth element, water element, fire element, wind element, and space element are impermanent and not solid.
The people of Brahma Heaven, whose rewards, appearance, and blessings are meager, will eventually die and be reborn as humans.
That person, with diligence, free from desires, with a single mind, will recall the Brahma Heaven according to the samÄdhi of the image of its appearance.
This is what that person says:

This is the second view.
Third, what do the non-Buddhist paths say?

It is said that there is a god named KÄ«á¹­Ägiri, who enjoys pleasures with others above. Later, he always does not think of illness and attachment to the bed. That person then says:
'Those heavenly beings who enjoy pleasures and happiness can always remain without changing and dying.
The human pleasures and happiness here are impermanent, insubstantial, and have an end.

This is the third view.

Fourth, if there are non-Buddhist practitioners who say that there is a god named Saá¹ƒjÄ«va, who resides above, living together, facing each other, giving rise to anger and leaving their original seats, then those gods and humans whose blessings and virtues are thin will die and be reborn among humans.

That person practices diligently, free from desires, with a single mind, and immediately, according to the image, in the samÄdhi concentration, recollects the heavens where he was born in the past. That person says:

Those gods are permanent, but I among humans am impermanent.
This is the fourth view.
The Buddha said:
All the non-Buddhist practitioners, each with their own teachings of permanence, each teaching worldly people about permanence, are all within these four views and cannot go beyond these four views.
The Buddha knows all of this, and even more than this, he knows the supreme, and therefore he does not criticize or slander, and attains non-action.

The Buddha knows pain, itching, and pleasure, and knows the means by which they arise, and their arising is seen. The Buddha's mind is free from attachment and well understands. The Dharma that the Buddha knows is profound and deeply illuminating, and I understand it all.
If there are wise disciples who hear and know this, they will praise the TathÄgata.

If there are non-Buddhist practitioners who, in the past eon, see past events and recall past practices, in incalculable ways, each delighting in explaining and understanding those events, they are all within the eighteen views.
What do the non-Buddhist practitioners know?
It is said that a non-Buddhist practitioner says:
I was born naturally here, not coming to be born from another place.
Recalling the view of having no origin, it is said that the world did not exist before but exists now.
They are all within the two views.
What do the non-Buddhist practitioners know?
It is said:
'I was born naturally here, not coming from elsewhere.'
Thinking that there was no world before, and that there is a world now, there is a god named No-thought, who enters into non-existence and has no thoughts or feelings.
If the people of that heaven think of thoughts, their merit and blessings will diminish and be exhausted, and they will die and be reborn in the world.

If a person practices diligently, separates from desires, and unifies their mind and intention, their intention will be like an image, and in that samÄdhi they will not be able to think of their past life.
That person will say:
'Originally there was no world, and now it has just come to be.
I did not exist before, and now I have been born naturally.'
This is the first view.
Second, if there is a non-Buddhist with deluded thoughts, that deluded person thinks:
'Originally there was no world, and now it has just come to be.
I did not exist before, and now I have been born by myself.
Why is it so?
I originally did not exist, but now I have self-existence. This is called the original non-existence of the world.
This is the second view.

The various non-Buddhist paths that say I originally came from nowhere, and the view that thinks of non-arising from nowhere, saying the world originally did not exist but now suddenly exists, are all within these two views. These two views cannot surpass this.
The Buddha knows all this and surpasses it with supreme knowledge.
Therefore, he does not criticize or disparage, and attains non-action.
The Buddha knows the pain and pleasure of change, knows the skillful means, and with insight, the Buddha's mind is well-liberated from arising.
The Buddha said:
The Dharma I know is profound and illuminating. I fully understand it.
If there are wise disciples who hear and know it, they will praise the Buddha.

If there are non-Buddhist practitioners who, in the past eon, see past events and recall past practices, and within the calculable path, each delights in speaking and understanding those matters, they are all within the eighteen views.

There are non-Buddhist practitioners, one person says my view has a limit, one person says my view is limitless, one person says my view has a limit and is limitless, one person says my view is neither limited nor limitless, they are all within these four views.
What do the non-Buddhist practitioners know?
If there are non-Buddhist practitioners who practice like this, they speak for the people of the world about having a limit, saying my words are sincere, and the rest are deluded and speak falsely.
They speak for the people of the world about being limitless, and speak like this:
'Some say I and the world have a limit and are limitless, and I and the world are neither limited nor limitless.
Later, it is also false speech, to say this is deceptive speech.
Why is it so?
I see the world as having a limit.
This is the first view.
Second, if there are non-Buddhist practitioners, what do they know?
They say:
I practice and see the world as having no limit, knowing that I and the world have no limit.
The non-Buddhist practitioners, seeing like this, practicing like this, say that I and the world have no limit. They say:
I and the world have no limit. I am sincere, the others are deluded.
They say in reverse:
I and the world have a limit and no limit, I and the world are neither limited nor limitless.
Those who say this are speaking falsely.
Why is it so?
I and the world have no limit.
This is the second view.
Third, if there are non-Buddhist practitioners, what do they know?
It is said that the non-Buddhist practitioners see and practice like this, saying:
'Know that I and the world are finite or infinite. What I say is true, the rest is foolish and false speech.
They say in return:
I and the world are finite and infinite, and I and the world are neither finite nor infinite.
Those who say this are speaking falsely.
Why is it so?
I and the world are finite and infinite.
This is the third view.
Fourth, if there are other practitioners, what do they know?
It is said that those people say:
I remember this way, I see this way, I know that I and the world are neither finite nor infinite. What I say is true, the rest is foolish and false speech.
They say in return:
I and the world are finite, I and the world are infinite, I and the world are finite and infinite.
Those who say this are speaking falsely.
Why is it so?
I and the world are neither finite nor infinite.
This is the fourth view.
The Buddha said:

All non-Buddhist paths say there are limits, say there are no limits, say there are both limits and no limits, and say there are neither limits nor no limits. As for me and the world, they are all within these four views and cannot go beyond these four views.
The Buddha knows all this and surpasses it with his sublime knowledge.
Therefore, he does not criticize or disparage, and attains non-action.
The Buddha knows the feelings and changes in pleasure, knows the methods that arise from them, does not accept or become attached to them, and the Buddha skillfully understands them.
The Buddha said:
The Dharma I know is profound and illuminating.
If there are wise disciples who hear and understand it, they will praise the Buddha.

If there are non-Buddhist practitioners who, in past eons, see past events and recall their past lives along countless paths, and each delights in explaining what they understand, they are all within these eighteen views.
The various non-Buddhist practitioners argue and speak differently. If someone asks a question, they argue and speak differently, saying:
Teach this person like this, teach that person like this, teach the others like this, teach people like this and not like this.
They are all within these four views.
What are the various non-Buddhist practitioners who argue and speak differently?
It means there are various non-Buddhist practitioners who see and practice like this, saying:
I do not know or see if there is an afterlife or not;
I do not know, there is no afterlife at all;
I also do not see, I do not see, know, or think about this matter. As I say, it is not like what others say.
That person speaks alone and acts on their own, saying:
What I see is sincere, the rest is foolish.
The Buddha said:
Those who accept and uphold the teachings of the foolish and the wrongly-viewed will, upon the death of their bodies, go to the evil paths of the hells.

If there are Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as whose practice is to know much, whose wisdom is to explain, whose meaning is to contemplate, whose speech is without error, whose fame reaches distant places, who abandon other views, who come to them, who ask them in a peaceful and correct manner, but who are unable to resolve [their doubts];
those non-Buddhists, upon death, will fall into the evil paths.
This is the first view.
What is the second non-Buddhist view?
It is that a non-Buddhist holds the view and speaks thus:
'I do not know whether there are good and evil consequences, nor do I know whether there are no good and evil consequences. I neither know nor see.
' If one speaks thus:
'I am attached to the existence of good and evil consequences, and I am detached from the non-existence of good and evil consequences. If I am not attached, I will turn back and accept [rebirth].

If there are Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as whose practice and knowledge are extensive, whose wisdom and explanations are profound, whose words are consistent with reality, whose fame spreads far and wide, who abandon other views, and who come to them to ask questions in a peaceful and sincere manner, they are unable to respond.
Those non-Buddhist practitioners are doubtful and afraid of being questioned. If there are questions, they argue and say:
Teach this person like this, and teach that person like this.
It should be like this and not like that, and it should also be like this and not like that.
This is the second view.
What is the third view?
It is said that the non-Buddhist practitioners' view and statement are like this:
We do not know what is good and what is evil.
What should we practice and what should we not practice?
What is an evil path and what is a good path?
What is a treasure in this world and what is a treasure in the next world?
What should one do to experience suffering, and what should one do to experience happiness?'

If there are Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as who practice much, have extensive knowledge and understanding, whose words are consistent with the truth, whose reputation spreads far and wide, who abandon other views, and come to them, they ask them in a peaceful and sincere manner:
'What is good and evil that should be practiced?
What should not be practiced?
What is the path of good and evil?
What is the treasure for this life and the next that should always be created?
What actions lead to suffering and happiness?'
When they come and ask, they are unable to respond, fearing the evil paths. If there are those who ask about matters, they argue with each other, their words contradicting each other:
'Teach such and such to do this, teach others to do that, teach people to do this, and also do not do that.'
This is the third view.
Fourth, if there are other path practitioners, what do they know?
It means that the minds of non-Buddhists are deluded. If someone asks a question, they argue and speak differently:
'Teach one person like this, teach another person like this, like this and not like this, also like this and not like this, also like this and not like this.
This is the fourth view.
Namely, non-Buddhists argue and speak differently. If someone asks a question, they argue and say:
'Teach one person like this, teach another person like this, like this and not like this, also like this and not like this.
All of this falls within the four views and cannot go beyond these four views. The Buddha knows all of this, and his knowledge surpasses and is wondrous.
Therefore, he does not criticize or slander, and attains non-action.
The Buddha knows pain, itching, and pleasure, and skillfully knows where they arise from. The Buddha manifests the well-understood mind of acceptance.
The Buddha said:
The Dharma I know is profound and illuminating. I have fully understood it.
If there are wise disciples who hear and know it, they will praise the Buddha.

If there are non-Buddhist practitioners who, in the past eon, know past events and recall past practices, and those who, in incalculable ways, each enjoy speaking and explaining those matters, they are all within these eighteen views. These eighteen views cannot surpass this.

The Buddha's knowledge is like this, and it surpasses this with even more wondrous knowledge. Therefore, he does not criticize or disparage, and the Buddha manifests the well-understood mind of acceptance without grasping.
The Buddha said:
The Dharma I know is profound and illuminating. I have fully understood it.
If there are wise disciples who hear and know it, they will praise the Buddha.

If there are non-Buddhist practitioners who, in the future eon, see future events, think of future events, and practice innumerable paths, each enjoying explaining those events, they are all within the forty-four views.
What do those non-Buddhist practitioners know?
It means that in the future eon, they know future events, practice innumerable paths, and each enjoy explaining those events.

It means practicing the view of conceptualization and expounding the view of conceptualization to worldly people, which are within the sixteen views.

'Neither finite nor infinite existence is the self. My truth, the rest are foolish.'

Ninth, if there are non-Buddhist practitioners who say:

'One pleasure constitutes the self. My sincerity is true, while the rest are deluded.'
This is the thirteenth view.

'Suffering constitutes the self. My sincerity is true, while the rest are deluded.'

The non-Buddhist practitioners who engage in views of existence and views of non-existence, and explain existence and non-existence to the world, are all within these sixteen views and cannot go beyond them.
The Buddha knows all of this, and his knowledge surpasses and is wondrous.
The Buddha knows this, and neither criticizes nor slanders, attaining non-action.
The Buddha knows feelings and their arising, and manifests without attachment, with a well-liberated mind.
The Buddha said:
The Dharma I know is profound and illuminating, and I fully understand it.
If there are wise disciples who hear and know this, they will praise the Buddha.
If there are non-Buddhist practitioners who, in the future eon, see future events and recall past practices, in countless ways they each enjoy explaining their doctrines, all within forty-four views.
What are the non-Buddhist doctrines?
Namely, if there are non-Buddhist practitioners who practice the view of annihilation and impermanence, and expound to worldly people that things are impermanent, they are all within the eight views.
What are the practices of those non-Buddhist practitioners?
Namely, practicing the view of non-thought and expounding to worldly people that things are without thought.
Those non-Buddhist practitioners see and practice thus, that there is form and self but no thought, and after death there is no afterlife.
They say:
I am sincere, the rest are deluded.
This is the first view.
Second, what do the non-Buddhist practitioners know?
Namely, practicing the view of non-thought and expounding to worldly people that things are without thought, saying:
There is no form, but there is self and no thought, and after death there is no afterlife. I am sincere, the rest are deluded.
This is the second view.
The third view, if there are non-Buddhist practitioners who say:
'There is a self with form and without form, without thought, and after death there is no afterlife. I am sincere, the rest are deluded.'
This is the third view.
The fourth view: If there is a non-Buddhist path, neither with form nor without form, there is a self and the world, and after death there is no afterlife. I am sincere, the rest are deluded.
This is the fourth view.
The fifth view: If there is a non-Buddhist path, it says:
'I am limited with the world, I am sincere, the rest are deluded.'
This is the fifth view.
The sixth view: If there is a non-Buddhist path, it says:
'I am unlimited with the world, I am sincere, the rest are deluded.'
This is the sixth view.ğŸ”½The seventh view: If there is a non-Buddhist path, it says:
'I am limited and unlimited, I am sincere, the rest are deluded.'
This is the seventh view.
The eighth view: If there are non-Buddhist practitioners who say:
Neither limited nor unlimited, I am sincere, the others are deluded.
This is the eighth view.
The Buddha said:
If there are non-Buddhist practitioners who, in the future eon, see future events, their different understandings fall within the forty-four views.
What do the non-Buddhist practitioners know?
They say that they see no thought and no thought-free state, and also not no-thought. They say they know that they and the world have no thoughts, all falling within these eight views.

The first view: If there are non-Buddhist practitioners who see and practice in this way, having form and a self, neither having thoughts nor being thought-free, having an afterlife, I am sincere, the others are deluded.
This is the first view.
If there are non-Buddhist practitioners who say:
'There is a self with form and without form, neither with perception nor without perception, after death, I am truthful, the rest are foolish.'
This is the second view.

This is the third view.ğŸ”½The fourth view, if there is a non-Buddhist who says:
'There is neither a self with form nor without form, neither with perception nor without perception in the afterlife, I am truthful, the rest are foolish.'
This is the fourth view.
The fifth view, if there is a non-Buddhist who says:
'There is a limited self, neither with perception nor without perception in the afterlife, I am truthful, the rest are foolish.'
This is the fifth view.
The sixth view: If there are non-Buddhists who say:
'There is a self that exists without limit, neither with nor without perception in the afterlife. My words are true, the rest are deluded.'
This is the sixth view.
The seventh view: If there are non-Buddhists who say:
'There is a self that exists both with limit and without limit, neither with nor without perception in the afterlife. My words are true, the rest are deluded.'
This is the seventh view.
The eighth view: If there are non-Buddhists who say:
'There is a self that exists neither with limit nor without limit, neither with nor without perception in the afterlife. My words are true, the rest are deluded.'
This is the eighth view. The Buddha said:

If there are non-Buddhist practitioners who practice neither with perception nor without perception, view neither with perception nor without perception, and neither practice nor view with perception, they are all within these eight views and cannot go beyond these eight views.
The Buddha knows all this, and his knowledge surpasses this, being supremely wondrous. Therefore, he does not criticize or disparage, and attains non-action.
The Buddha knows the feelings, changes, and pleasures, and skillfully knows their origins. The Buddha manifests liberation with an unattached mind.
The Buddha said:
The Dharma I know is profound and illuminating, and I fully understand it.
If there are virtuous disciples who hear and know this, they will then speak of the Buddha's merits.
The Buddha said:
If there are non-Buddhist practitioners who see future events in the future, and with innumerable paths, their knowledge and words are different, they are all within forty-four views.
What do the non-Buddhist practitioners know?
Namely, if there are non-Buddhist practitioners who say:
There is no practice, no view, and no one who thinks of emptiness and knowledge.
They are all within the seven views.
Those non-Buddhist practitioners say:
There is no practice, no view, and no one who thinks of emptiness. What is known?

Namely, if there are non-Buddhist practitioners who see such and such aspects of the self, with form, the four elements, born from parents, nourished by food and drink, impermanent, bathed and clothed, the body dies on the ground, the bones disintegrate and fall apart, separated in different places, the body blown by the wind, shattered and destroyed, in the afterlife not reborn again, thus ceasing to exist.
This is the first view.
The second view, there are other non-Buddhist practitioners who say:
Death is not like this destruction, there is another self that surpasses it.
What is the self that surpasses it?
The self refers to the gods of form and desire realm gods. When that self dies and perishes, it does not undergo rebirth in the next world.
This is the second view.
The third view, if there are non-Buddhist practitioners who say:
'The self when dying is not destroyed, there is another self that surpasses it.
That self is formless and without intention. When that self dies and perishes, it does not undergo rebirth in the next world.
'This is the third view.
The fourth view, again there are non-Buddhist practitioners who say:
'The self when dying is not destroyed, there is another self that surpasses it.
What is that self?
It refers to the self that transcends all the gods of the realm of form, surpasses all the gods of the realm of desire, and contemplates various infinite space and consciousness.
When that self dies and perishes, it does not undergo rebirth in the next world.
This is the fourth view.
The fifth view, again there are non-Buddhist practitioners who say:
'My self is not like that which perishes when the body is destroyed. There is another self that transcends it.
What is that self?
It refers to the self that surpasses all the gods who know the sky, the countless gods who know the mind,
and the gods who practice what they think. If one does not perish, then in the next life one will not be subject to birth and death again.'
This is the fifth view.
The sixth view is that of another non-Buddhist practitioner who says:
'My self is not like that which perishes when the body is destroyed. There is another self that transcends it.
What is that self?
It refers to the self that surpasses all the gods who know the mind, and no longer attaches to the gods who do not think.
When that self perishes, in the next life one will not be subject to birth and death again.'
This is the sixth view.
The seventh view is that of another non-Buddhist practitioner who says:
'My self is not like that which perishes when the body is destroyed. There is another self that transcends it.
What is that self?
It means surpassing all the heavens where there is no consciousness.
The heavenly beings in that heaven have no thoughts or conceptual activities.
When the heavenly beings die and perish, they will not be reborn in the next life.
This is the seventh view.
The Buddha said:
The non-Buddhist practitioners' views of annihilation, which are devoid of action, thought, and human existence, are all included within these seven views. They cannot go beyond the seven views.
The Buddha knows all this, and his knowledge surpasses and transcends theirs. Therefore, he does not criticize or slander them, and has attained non-action.
Because the Buddha knows the feelings, changes, and pleasures, he then knows their origin, and manifests their origin with an unattached mind, skillfully understanding.
The Dharma I know is profound and illuminating, and I fully understand it.
If there are wise disciples who hear and know this, they will then speak of the Buddha's merits.
The Buddha said:
If there are non-Buddhist practitioners who, in the future eon, see the future, in countless ways, what they say will all be within the forty-four views.
There are also non-Buddhist practitioners who say:
'Now, in the present, I practice and realize the unconditioned, and I see the unconditioned in the present.
' If someone comes to them, they will explain:
'The unconditioned in the present.'
All are within the five views.
There are non-Buddhist practitioners who see in this way and speak in this way, and they dwell in palaces, delighting in the five desires and entertaining themselves.
Those people say:
'I now attain the unconditioned.'
This is the first view.
The second view is that there are non-Buddhist practitioners who say:
'Unlike what others say about the existence of a self, there is now the attainment of the unconditioned.
What is meant by the unconditioned in the present?

The Buddha said:

Those who are called Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as who speak of the present as unconditioned, who see the present as unconditioned, who think of the present as unconditioned, are all within these five views and cannot go beyond these five views.
The Buddha knows all this, and his knowledge surpasses and is wondrously superior.

The Buddha knows the feelings, changes, and pleasures, and skillfully knows their origin and manifestation. The Buddha's mind is free from attachment and well understands. The Dharma I know is profound and illuminating, and I fully understand it.
If there are virtuous disciples who hear and know this, they will then speak of the Buddha's merits.
The Buddha said:
Those non-Buddhist practitioners who think of permanence and see permanence speak to others, saying:

Only then will you know that the conditions for practice and the conditions for non-practice are used to form conditions, and that the conditions for non-practice are not used to form conditions, and you will not find a place for them.

Only then will they know that the conditions for practice and the conditions for non-practice are used to form conditions, and they will not find a place for the conditions for non-practice.
The Buddha said:

If there are non-Buddhist paths that each think of eternalism and speak of the self and the world having permanence, falling into the four views, it is because of not knowing, not seeing, and thus not attaining the path. The conditions for practice and the conditions for non-practice are used to form conditions, and the conditions for non-practice are not used to form conditions, and they will not find a place for them.
The Buddha said:

Those non-Buddhist practitioners say there is a limit, or say there is no limit, or say there is both a limit and no limit, or say there is neither a limit nor no limit. As for me and the world being within the four views, it is because they do not know, do not see, and do not attain the path through diligent practice. Only then do they know the causes and conditions of practice and non-practice.
Because of these causes and conditions, they succeed or fail, and do not find their place.
The Buddha said:

Those non-Buddhist practitioners argue and speak differently, being within the four views. It is because they do not know, do not see, and do not attain the path through diligent practice. Only then do they know the causes and conditions of practice and non-practice.
Because of these causes and conditions, they succeed or fail, and do not find their place.
The Buddha said:
Those non-Buddhist practitioners speak of the conceptual thoughts and practices of conceptual thoughts, and tell people:
'I and the world have conceptual thoughts.
Among the sixteen views, due to not knowing and not seeing, one cannot attain the path, practice diligently, and understand the causes and conditions of practice and non-practice.
Due to these causes and conditions, one cannot attain the proper place of accomplishment and non-accomplishment.
The Buddha said:

and understand the causes and conditions of practice and non-practice.
Due to these causes and conditions, they cannot attain the proper place of accomplishment and non-accomplishment.
The Buddha said:
Those non-Buddhist practitioners who neither contemplate thought nor non-thought, and explain to others:
'The self and the world are non-thought.'
Are among the eight views. Due to not knowing and not seeing, they cannot attain the path, practice diligently.
Only then can one know the causes and conditions of practice and non-practice.
Using these causes and conditions, one may succeed or fail, but one will not find the right place.
The Buddha said:
Those non-Buddhist paths speak of annihilation, and always tell people:
'The self and the world are annihilated.'
Those who are in the seven views do not know and see, and therefore cannot attain the path, practice diligently,
Only then can one know the causes and conditions of practice and non-practice.
Using these causes and conditions, one may succeed or fail, but one will not find the right place.
The Buddha said:

Those non-Buddhist paths speak of the present as being without action, seeing the present as impermanent, and tell people that the present is without action. Those in the five views do not know and see, and therefore cannot attain the path, practice diligently.
Only then can one know the causes and conditions of practice and non-practice.
Using these causes and conditions, one may succeed or fail, but one will not find the right place.
The Buddha said:
If there are non-Buddhist practitioners who, in the past eons, see events of the past, in innumerable ways, each different, within the eighteen views,

and if those non-Buddhist practitioners, in the future eons, see events of the future, in innumerable ways, each explained differently, within the forty-four views, they are all included within these sixty-two views, going back and forth within them, dwelling there, giving rise to all activities within them, and are unable to escape from birth and death within the net.
The Buddha said:
It is like a skilled fisherman or his apprentice, who uses a small-meshed net to cast down into a small spring, and then sits or stands in front of it. That person thinks:
'The water is shallow, and all the floating and swimming fish will rise to the top of the net.
They will often be caught within it and unable to escape.'
The Buddha said:

Thus, all these non-Buddhist practitioners, in the past eon, saw past events, recognized past practices, and spoke of various paths, each with different teachings, falling into the eighteen views. If there are non-Buddhist practitioners who, in the future eon, see future events and think of speaking of future events, on various paths, each with different teachings, falling into the forty-four views, they are all within these sixty-two views, going back and forth, dwelling within them, and transmigrating within them, all together, entangled in the net, unable to escape.
